alert.note: Alert for San Luis Obispo (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued March 10 at 6:19AM PST until March 10 at 1:00PM PST by NWS Oxnard
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 1115 AM PST THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...western and central San Luis Obispo County. * WHEN...Until 1115 AM PST. * IMPACTS...Widespread ponding of water on area roadways and flooding of low-lying areas and intersections continues across the advisory area. Mudslides and rockslides are likely on canyon roads. There will likely be additional rises in small streams and creeks. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 610 AM PST, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated moderate to heavy rain across most of the advisory area, with rainfall rates of one quarter to one half inch per hour. - Moderate to heavy rain will continue through the morning, resulting in widespread ponding of water, flooding of low lying areas and intersections, as well as rises in creeks and streams. A flash flood warning is also in effect for the northwestern portion of San Luis Obispo County, where life threatening flash flooding is expected. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... San Luis Obispo, Paso Robles, Morro Bay, Pismo Beach, Atascadero, Arroyo Grande, Nipomo, Cambria, Point Piedras Blancas, Grover Beach, Santa Margarita, Highway 101 over Cuesta Grade, Templeton, Lake Lopez, Black Mountain, Shell Beach, Avila Beach, Baywood-Los Osos and Oceano. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: The rain will likely trigger shallow mud and debris flows, minor rock falls, and flooding capable of localized damage, especially in steep terrain. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads.
